comment.author: 40928506@N04
comment._content:
Out of interest, where did the information about this man come from? Because I can't even find him in 'Soldiers Died' or the CWGC. There are some that are close, but no definite match for the information you have here.
Andy.

comment.author: 40928506@N04
comment._content:
This man is the nearest match:
ATKINSON, WILLIAM
Rank: Private
Service No:51077
Date of Death:  29/03/1918
Age: 27
Regiment/Service: Northumberland Fusiliers  1st Bn. 
Panel Reference Bay 2 and 3.
Memorial ARRAS MEMORIAL
Additional Information: Son of William and Annie Atkinson, of The Peth, Longtown, Cumberland.

comment.author: 91614361@N08
comment._content:
From experience I think it's more likely to be:
ATKINSON, WILLIAM
Rank:
Able Seaman
Service No:
R/4259
Date of Death:
21/03/1918
Age:
23
Regiment/Service:
Royal Naval Volunteer Reserve
 
Hawke Bn. R.N. Div.
Grave Reference
II. F. 28.
Cemetery
ACHIET-LE-GRAND COMMUNAL CEMETERY EXTENSION
Additional Information:
Son of Samuel and Lucy Atkinson, of 4, Balls Rd. East, Birkenhead.
Although part of the RND, this man had previous service with the 4th Bn Cheshire Regt up to 1917. Its therefore possible that before this he had also served with the 22nd Bn Northumberland Fus. The cemetery he is buried in is also not a million miles away from the Bullecourt area, as well as the same date of death.

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content:
The shoulder titles worn by this soldier are certainly those of a Regular or Territorial Northumberland Fusiliers battalion, (the letters N F either side of a flaming grenade) as opposed to the 22nd Battalion which was 3rd Battalion Tyneside Scottish (the words TYNESIDE SCOTTISH). This tends to support the suggestion that this is Pte William Atkinson of 1st Battalion Northumberland Fusiliers and that 29th March has been misread as 21st March.  

22nd Northumberland Fusiliers (Tyneside Scottish) was overrun in front of Croiselles on 21st March 1918.  1st Battalion Northumberland Fusiliers fought near Bullecourt to the south of Arras on 29th March 1918, helping to bring to a standstill the Operation Mars phase of the Ludendorff Spring Offensive.//

comment.author: 78785369@N06
comment._content: Private William Atkinson of the Northumberland Fusiliers is commemorated on one of two tablets to the fallen of World War One in the Arthuret Parish Church at Longtown.  These were unveiled by Lieutenant General Sir Beauvoir De Lisle KCB KCMG DSO on 8th February 1921.

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content:
1911 Census  Samuel (age 40) and Lucy Atkinson (age 39), son William Atkinson (age 17, clerk)
are living at 18 West St, Newton By Chester.
1911 Census William (age 67) and Annie (age 58), son Frank William Atkinson (age 22, b Crosby Rovensworth West Skelton Cumberland Address:Lamonby House Skelton Penrith, working on father's farm)  see suggestion by Andy Wade1 but may not fit because of the name Frank.
